subtitle: C
sectionText:
SEC. 80301. RESCISSION OF FOREST SERVICE FUNDS.

    Paragraph (4) of section 23001(a) of Public Law 117-169 is repealed 
and all unobligated balances of amounts made available under such 
paragraph are hereby rescinded.
summary: Repeals § 23001(a)(4) of the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) and claws back every unobligated dollar it appropriated to the U.S. Forest Service for climate‑smart forest stewardship, hazardous‑fuels reduction, and carbon‑sequestration projects.
impact:
• **Fire‑risk whiplash.**  The IRA money targeted thinning and prescribed‑burn backlogs on 10 million acres; rescission halts contracts already queued for the 2025 burn window, heightening wildfire exposure for Western communities.
• **Private‑sector chill.**  Biochar, carbon‑credit and mill expansions that banked on steady Forest Service feedstock may stall, discouraging private capital in wood‑products innovation.
• **Budget seesaw.**  Short‑term deficit savings (~$5 bn unobligated) are likely offset by higher future suppression costs—federal wildfire spending averaged $4 bn/yr over the last five years.
• **Equity gap widens.**  Tribal and rural‑county stewardship grants—many in environmental‑justice zones—lose a rare dedicated funding stream.

subtitle: C
sectionTitle: Rescission of National Park Service and Bureau of Land Management Funds
sectionText:
SEC. 80302. RESCISSION OF NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND BUREAU OF LAND 
              MANAGEMENT FUNDS.

    There is hereby rescinded the unobligated balances of amounts made 
available by section 50221 of Public Law 117-169.
summary: Cancels all unobligated IRA § 50221 dollars that were slated for habitat connectivity, drought resilience, and ecosystem restoration on National Park Service (NPS) and Bureau of Land Management (BLM) lands.
impact:
• **Project cliff‑edge.**  Landscape‑scale wildlife corridor and invasive‑species grants now face termination mid‑NEPA review, stranding state and NGO co‑funding already committed.
• **Visitor‑experience decline.**  Park road and trail climate‑proofing projects lose funding, leading to more washouts and closures that cut tourism revenue for gateway towns.
• **BLM trust deficit.**  States pushing for shared stewardship may view the rescission as federal unreliability, complicating future cooperative agreements.
• **Marginal deficit gain** relative to deferred‑maintenance liabilities that will still require future appropriations.

subtitle: C
sectionTitle: Rescission of BLM and NPS Funds
sectionText:
SEC. 80303. RESCISSION OF BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT AND NATIONAL PARK 
              SERVICE FUNDS.

    There is hereby rescinded the unobligated balances of amounts made 
available by section 50222 of Public Law 117-169.
summary: Eliminates the remaining unobligated IRA § 50222 funds intended for hiring and habitat‑restoration capacity at BLM and NPS.
impact:
• **Staffing freeze.**  Planned seasonal‑crew expansions for invasive‑plant removal and cultural‑site stabilization evaporate, exacerbating backlog growth.
• **Contractor ripple.**  Conservation corps and small businesses that won provisional task orders lose work, affecting rural employment.
• **Monitoring gap.**  Funds earmarked for climate‑impact monitoring stations are withdrawn, shrinking datasets used for water‑supply forecasting.

subtitle: C
sectionTitle: Rescission of National Park Service Funds
sectionText:
SEC. 80304. RESCISSION OF NATIONAL PARK SERVICE FUNDS.

    There is hereby rescinded the unobligated balances of amounts made 
available by section 50223 of Public Law 117-169.
summary: Rescinds all unobligated IRA § 50223 dollars that were reserved for NPS climate‑adaptation and legacy restoration projects (e.g., wetland revival, coastal fortification).
impact:
• **Shoreline erosion accelerates.**  Cancelled marsh‑restoration work at parks like Cape Hatteras leaves visitor infrastructure vulnerable to storms.
• **Lost matching dollars.**  States and philanthropies that conditioned donations on IRA match will likely pull funds, multiplying the shortfall.
• **Deferred‑maintenance balloon.**  Restoration would have reduced $22 bn backlog; rescission lets liabilities compound at 8 % annually per GAO.

subtitle: C
sectionText:
SEC. 80305. CELEBRATING AMERICA'S 250TH ANNIVERSARY.

    In addition to amounts otherwise available, there is appropriated 
to the Secretary of the Interior for fiscal year 2025, out of any money 
in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, to remain available through 
fiscal year 2028--
            (1) $150,000,000 for events, celebrations, and activities 
        related to the observance and commemoration of the 250th 
        anniversary of the founding of the United States; and
            (2) $40,000,000 to carry out Executive Order 13934 of July 
        3, 2020 (85 Fed. Reg. 41165), Executive Order 13978 of January 
        18, 2021 (86 Fed. Reg. 6809), and Executive Order 14189 of 
        January 29, 2025 (90 Fed. Reg. 8849) to establish and maintain 
        a statuary park to be known as the National Garden of American 
        Heroes.
summary: Appropriates $150 million (FY 2025‑2028) for semiquincentennial events plus $40 million to build and maintain the National Garden of American Heroes envisioned in three Trump‑era executive orders.
impact:
• **Cultural‑spending pivot.**  New commemorative funds offset some rescissions above but shift focus from conservation to patriotic displays, raising debate over priorities amid maintenance backlogs.
• **Site‑selection controversy.**  The Garden’s location and statue selection spurred earlier partisan disputes; fresh funding re‑opens those fights and possible NEPA or tribal‑consultation challenges.
• **Economic bump.**  Short‑term boost for event planners, sculptors and construction trades, but uncertain long‑term operating funds could leave NPS with another asset to maintain without revenue stream.

subtitle: C
sectionTitle: Long‑Term Contracts for the Forest Service
sectionText:
SEC. 80306. LONG-TERM CONTRACTS FOR THE FOREST SERVICE.

    (a) In General.--For each of fiscal years 2025 through 2034, the 
Chief of the Forest Service (in this section referred to as the 
``Chief'') shall enter into not less than one long-term contract or 
agreement with private persons or other public or private entities 
under section 14(a) of the National Forest Management Act (16 U.S.C. 
472a(a)) with respect to covered National Forest System lands in each 
region of the Forest Service that contains covered National Forest 
System lands.
    (b) Terms.--
            (1) In general.--Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and 
        (3), the Chief shall enter into contracts or agreements under 
        subsection (a) in accordance with section 3903 of title 41, 
        United States Code, and section 14 of the National Forest 
        Management Act (16 U.S.C. 472a).
            (2) Contract length.--The period of a contract or agreement 
        under subsection (a) shall be for at least 20 years, with 
        options for extensions and renewals as determined by the Chief.
            (3) Cancellation ceilings.--A contract or agreement entered 
        into under subsection (a) shall include provisions for a 
        cancellation ceiling consistent with section 604(d) of the 
        Healthy Forests Restoration Act of 2003 (16 U.S.C. 6591c(d)).
    (c) Receipts.--Any monies derived from an agreement or contract 
under this section by the Chief shall be deposited in the general fund 
of the Treasury.
    (d) Covered National Forest System Lands Defined.--In this section, 
the term ``covered National Forest System lands'' means the proclaimed 
National Forest System lands reserved or withdrawn from the public 
domain of the United States.
summary: Mandates that each Forest Service region execute at least one 20‑year stewardship or timber‑supply contract annually (2025‑2034) for National Forest lands, with cancellation ceilings modeled on existing 10‑year stewardship authorities.
impact:
• **Market certainty vs. monopoly risk.**  Long horizons can revive shuttered mills and bioenergy plants, but locking up large volumes with single operators may stifle competition and undercut smaller businesses.
• **Fiscal exposure.**  20‑year cancellation ceilings create contingent liabilities for the Treasury if future appropriations falter or litigation halts projects.
• **Environmental oversight strain.**  Mega‑contracts spanning decades complicate adaptive management and may embed outdated silvicultural prescriptions in a changing climate.

subtitle: C
sectionTitle: Long‑Term Contracts for the Bureau of Land Management
sectionText:
SEC. 80307. LONG-TERM CONTRACTS FOR THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT.

    (a) In General.--For each of fiscal years 2025 through 2034, the 
Director of the Bureau of Land Management (in this section referred to 
as the ``Director'') shall enter into not less than one long-term 
contract or agreement with private persons or other public or private 
entities under section 1 of the Materials Act of 1947 (30 U.S.C. 601) 
with respect to vegetative materials on covered public lands.
    (b) Terms.--
            (1) In general.--Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and 
        (3), the Director shall enter into contracts or agreements 
        under subsection (a) in accordance with section 3903 of title 
        41, United States Code, and section 2(a) of the Materials Act 
        of 1947 (30 U.S.C. 602(a)).
            (2) Contract length.--The period of a contract or agreement 
        under subsection (a) shall be for at least 20 years, with 
        options for extensions and renewals as determined by the 
        Director.
            (3) Cancellation ceilings.--A contract or agreement entered 
        into under subsection (a) shall include provisions for a 
        cancellation ceiling consistent with section 604(d) of the 
        Healthy Forests Restoration Act of 2003 (16 U.S.C. 6591c(d)).
    (c) Location.--In selecting locations to enter into long-term 
contracts or agreements under subsection (a), the Director shall 
prioritize areas with no existing wood processing infrastructure.
    (d) Receipts.--Any monies derived from an agreement or contract 
under this section by the Director shall be deposited in the general 
fund of the Treasury.
    (e) Covered Public Lands Defined.--The term ``covered public 
lands'' has the meaning given the term ``public lands'' in section 103 
of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1702), 
except that the term includes Coos Bay Wagon Road Grant lands and 
Oregon and California Railroad Grant lands.
summary: Requires BLM to execute at least one 20‑year vegetative‑material contract per year in each region lacking existing wood‑processing infrastructure, with terms paralleling Forest Service provisions.
impact:
• **Biomass build‑out.**  Could spark new pellet and bioenergy facilities in sagebrush states, helping fund cheatgrass removal—but may also incentivise over‑harvest if monitoring lags.
• **Rural‑economic gamble.**  Industry investment hinges on sustained feedstock; if future administrations alter harvest targets, plants could strand.
• **Administrative load.**  BLM historically issues short‑term sales; scaling to multi‑decade agreements strains an agency already thin on foresters.

subtitle: C
sectionTitle: Timber Production for the Forest Service
sectionText:
SEC. 80308. TIMBER PRODUCTION FOR THE FOREST SERVICE.

    (a) In General.--Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment 
of this title, the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Chief 
of the Forest Service or their designee, shall direct timber harvest on 
covered National Forest System lands in amounts that--
            (1) in total, equal or exceed the volume that is 25 percent 
        higher than the average of the total volume sold on such lands 
        between fiscal years 2020 through 2024; and
            (2) are in accordance with the applicable forest plan, 
        including the allowable sale quantity or probable sale 
        quantity, as applicable, of timber applicable to such lands on 
        the date of enactment of this title.
    (b) Definitions.--In this section:
            (1) Covered national forest system lands.--
                    (A) In general.--Except as provided in subparagraph 
                (B), the term ``covered National Forest System lands'' 
                means the proclaimed National Forest System lands 
                reserved or withdrawn from the public domain of the 
                United States.
                    (B) Exclusions.--The term ``covered National Forest 
                System lands'' does not include lands--
                            (i) that are included in the National 
                        Wilderness Preservation System;
                            (ii) that are located within a national or 
                        State-specific inventoried roadless area 
                        established by the Secretary of Agriculture 
                        through regulation, unless--
                                    (I) the forest management activity 
                                to be carried out under such authority 
                                is consistent with the forest plan 
                                applicable to the area; or
                                    (II) the activity is allowed under 
                                the applicable roadless rule governing 
                                such lands, including--
                                            (aa) the Idaho roadless 
                                        rule under subpart C of part 
                                        294 of title 36, Code of 
                                        Federal Regulations;
                                            (bb) the Colorado roadless 
                                        rule under subpart D of part 
                                        294 of title 36, Code of 
                                        Federal Regulations; or
                                            (cc) any other roadless 
                                        rule developed after the date 
                                        of the enactment of this 
                                        section by the Secretary with 
                                        respect to a specific State; or
                            (iii) on which timber harvesting for any 
                        purpose is prohibited by Federal statute.
            (2) Forest plan.--The term ``forest plan'' means a land and 
        resource management plan prepared by the Forest Service for a 
        unit of the National Forest System pursuant to section 6 of the 
        Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 
        (16 U.S.C. 1604).
summary: Orders the Forest Service to increase annual timber volume sold on most National Forest lands by at least 25 % over the FY 2020‑2024 average, within existing forest‑plan allowable‑sale ceilings.
impact:
• **Supply surge vs. capacity reality.**  A 25 % bump (~600 MMBF) exceeds milling capacity in many regions; unsold offerings could inflate program costs without revenue gains.
• **Litigation spike.**  Larger sales likely rely on categorical exclusions; NGOs are poised to litigate, potentially freezing targets and inflating planning costs.
• **Carbon accounting.**  Greater removals reduce standing‑stock sequestration; without slash‑burn or bio‑energy outlets, post‑harvest emissions could offset wildfire‑risk benefits.

subtitle: C
sectionTitle: Timber Production for the Bureau of Land Management
sectionText:
SEC. 80309. TIMBER PRODUCTION FOR THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT.

    (a) In General.--Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment 
of this title, the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the 
Director of the Bureau of Land Management or their designee, shall 
direct timber harvest on covered public lands in amounts that--
            (1) in total, equal or exceed the volume that is 25 percent 
        higher than the average of the total volume sold on such lands 
        between fiscal years 2020 through 2024; and
            (2) are in accordance with the applicable forest plan.
    (b) Definitions.--In this section:
            (1) Covered public lands.--
                    (A) In general.--Except as provided in subparagraph 
                (B), the term ``covered public lands'' has the meaning 
                given the term ``public lands'' in section 103 of the 
                Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 
                U.S.C. 1702), except that the term includes Coos Bay 
                Wagon Road Grant lands and Oregon and California 
                Railroad Grant lands.
                    (B) Exclusions.--The term ``covered public lands'' 
                does not include lands--
                            (i) that are included in the National 
                        Wilderness Preservation System; or
                            (ii) on which timber harvesting for any 
                        purpose is prohibited by Federal statute.
            (2) Forest plan.--The term ``forest plan'' means a land use 
        plan prepared by the Bureau of Land Management for public lands 
        pursuant to section 202 of the Federal Land Policy and 
        Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1712).
summary: Directs BLM to raise timber volume sold on covered public lands, including Oregon & California Railroad lands, by at least 25 % over the FY 2020‑2024 average, consistent with land‑use plans.
impact:
• **O&C counties benefit—maybe.**  Higher cut targets promise more shared timber receipts, but court‑ordered Northern Spotted Owl protections have historically constrained O&C harvests; litigation could bottleneck gains.
• **Capacity mismatch.**  Pacific Northwest mills have modernised for small logs; if increased volume is low‑grade material, market absorption may lag.
• **ESA & NEPA tension.**  BLM already loses ~70 % of litigated timber cases; accelerating volume without parallel consultation capacity could worsen backlog and undermine targets.
